submission.title: Name Chain–Anchored Digital Artifacts with Interoperable Authentication Marks
submission.overview: This pattern enables any digital object—text, credential, file, token—to carry a human-readable name (e.g., @name/object) and a verifiable, interoperable mark of authentication. These objects can travel across the open web while retaining provenance, trust context, and actionable semantics. The system allows for persistent identity, cross-platform verification, and composability of trustable content, providing a semantic envelope for use in overlays, presence layers, or public ledgers. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3. This submission was inspired by a conversation with Jaime Schwartz about his name chain and provenance tech.

directly_addressed_dps.summary: Allows digital artifacts to carry authenticated provenance, supporting modular and federated trust resolution.
Individuals can mint, sign, challenge, or verify named objects across contexts without reliance on a single platform.
Utilizes name chains (@user/object) as decentralized pointers with verifiable semantics and conflict resolution logic.
Ensures digital artifacts retain cryptographic marks, signature chains, and verifiable metadata as they propagate.

clarifications_and_extensions.title: Interoperable Trust Marks for Multi-Format Artifacts
clarifications_and_extensions.clarification: Authentication marks are not bound to a specific format or issuer. The architecture supports a modular resolver model capable of interpreting claims across formats (e.g., JSON-LD, PDF metadata, DIDs, NFTs, IMA containers).
clarifications_and_extensions.why_it_matters: Without flexible and interoperable trust anchors, authentication systems fragment across silos. A shared approach ensures continuity of trust even as artifacts move between overlay networks.

clarifications_and_extensions.title: Name Chains as URI-Resolvable Trust Anchors
clarifications_and_extensions.extension: Name chains (e.g., @jaime/artifact99) function as semantic, URI-like identifiers with resolution pathways that combine identity verification and object authentication.
clarifications_and_extensions.why_it_matters: This extends DNS-style naming into the trust layer of the Metaweb, enabling structured reference to people, objects, and assertions in a verifiable and user-controlled manner.

clarifications_and_extensions.title: Challenge-Response and Endorsement Histories
clarifications_and_extensions.extension: Trust marks optionally include challenge-response trails, timestamped endorsements, or revocation notices, layered into a common verification envelope.
clarifications_and_extensions.why_it_matters: Trust isn't binary; surfacing historical context of authentication (who signed, who challenged, who endorsed) allows recipients to make nuanced trust decisions.
